title: Evaluation of Web-based Training to Educate Physicians in the Methods of Interpreting Florbetapir-PET Scans
description_brief: This study will investigate the performance of physician readers trained to read florbetapir-PET scans using electronic media training.
description_detailed:
Avid has previously developed a florbetapir-PET scan binary read methodology and training program, which was successfully applied in studies 18F-AV-45-A08(NCT01565369), 18F-AV-45-A09(NCT01565382) and 18F-AV-45-A16(NCT01447719). In these previous studies, training was conducted in-person. Study 18F-AV-45-PT01 will evaluate an automated version of this training program suitable for web-based distribution. Nuclear medicine physicians will complete the automated training program then read the florbetapir-PET images from 151 subjects with repeat readings of 33 randomly selected images. Readers will rate each case as either positive for significant tracer accumulation in cortical gray matter or negative for significant tracer accumulation in cortical gray matter. The inter-rater reliability, sensitivity and specificity of the readers will be evaluated.

The primary image set for determination of inter-reader agreement is comprised of images from 119 subjects from two previous clinical studies (A07\[NCT00857415\]/A16\[NCT01447719\] and A05\[NCT00702143\]). This included all 59 subjects who came to autopsy in Study A07(NCT00857415) and it's follow-up study, A16(NCT01447719), and a set of 60 cases randomly selected from Study A05(NCT00702143) subjects, including 20 cognitively-normal controls, 20 with mild cognitive impairment) MCI, 20 with AD.

Subsequently, the protocol was amended to include all remaining A05(NCT00702143) MCI patients that were not used in the training program (n=32); 13 of these 32 scans presented for repeat reading (to increase the number of A05 MCI cases with repeated reads to 20). This increased the number of unique cases in the validation dataset to 151 scans with 33 scans repeated yielding a total of 184 scans reviewed by the readers.

participantFlowModule.recruitmentDetails: NO SUBJECTS WERE ENROLLED IN THIS STUDY - this study re-read scans obtained in other clinical studies

groups.title: Florbetapir-PET Scans
groups.description: All subject scans with a valid florbetapir-PET scan

groups.title: Florbetapir-PET Scans
groups.description: All subjects with a valid florbetapir-PET scan (59 from study A07/A16 and 92 from study A05)

outcomeMeasures.title: Inter-rater Reliability
outcomeMeasures.description: Measure of agreement among five readers using a binary read method (amyloid positive/negative) calculated using Fleiss' kappa. All scans were read in a blinded fashion without access to clinical information.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: 59 autopsy subjects (study A07\[NCT00857415\]/A16\[NCT01447719\]) + 20 healthy controls + 20 mild cognitive impairment + 20 AD (from study A05\[NCT00702143\])

outcomeMeasures.title: Sensitivity of Florbetapir-PET to Detect Moderate to Frequent Beta-amyloid Neuritic Plaques (Probable/Definite Alzheimer's Disease)
outcomeMeasures.description: Calculated as the percent of true positives which are correctly identified
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: at autopsy, within 2 years of scan

groups.title: All Autopsy
groups.description: Subjects with a valid florbetapir-PET scan and autopsy (including those who deceased more than 12 months after the scan)

groups.title: Autopsy Within One Year of Scan
groups.description: Subjects with a valid florbetapir-PET scan and autopsy (only those who deceased less than 12 months after the scan)

outcomeMeasures.title: Specificity of Florbetapir-PET to Detect no or Sparse Beta-amyloid Neuritic Plaques (Probable/Definite Alzheimer's Disease)
outcomeMeasures.description: Calculated as the percent of true negatives which are correctly identified
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: at autopsy, within 2 years of scan

groups.title: All Autopsy
groups.description: Subjects with a valid florbetapir-PET scan and autopsy (including those who deceased more than 12 months after the scan)

groups.title: Autopsy Within One Year of Scan
groups.description: Subjects with a valid florbetapir-PET scan and autopsy (only those who deceased less than 12 months after the scan)

outcomeMeasures.title: Inter-reader Reliability
outcomeMeasures.description: Measure of agreement among multiple readers using binary read method (Fleiss' kappa). Where available, histopathology analysis at autopsy was the truth standard (TS).
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: 59 from study A07(NCT00857415)/A16(NCT01447719) and 92 from study A05(NCT00702143)

groups.title: All Florbetapir-PET Scans
groups.description: All subjects with a valid florbetapir-PET scan

outcomeMeasures.title: Median Sensitivity and Specificity vs. CERAD Diagnosis
outcomeMeasures.description: Median sensitivity and specificity for 5 independent readers to detect moderate to frequent amyloid plaques (per CERAD criteria).

outcomeMeasures.title: Individual Reader Results (All Scans With Autopsy)
outcomeMeasures.description: Reader results (number of false negatives and number of false positives) for blinded independent readers. There were a total of 39 positive and 20 negative scans based on histopathology at autopsy.

groups.title: All Autopsy Population
groups.description: Group of subjects with valid images who came to autopsy within 2 year of scan

outcomeMeasures.title: Individual Reader Results (Autopsy Within 1 Year of Scan)
outcomeMeasures.description: Reader results (number of false negatives and number of false positives) for blinded independent readers. There were a total of 28 positive and 18 negative scans based on histopathology at autopsy.

groups.title: Autopsy Within One Year of Scan
groups.description: Group of subjects with valid images who came to autopsy within 1 year of scan

adverseEventsModule.description: No subjects received florbetapir in this study. This study consisted of re-reads of scans previously acquired in other clinical studies (A05, A07, A16).

eventGroups.title: Florbetapir-PET Scans
eventGroups.description: All subject scans with a valid florbetapir-PET scan

drug: Florbetapir (18F) — PET amyloid imaging agent (trade name: Amyvid)
explanation_target: Reason: The study description and title say the trial evaluates web-based training for physician readers to interpret florbetapir-PET scans. That indicates a diagnostic/reader-training study (improving image-read performance), not a therapeutic intervention intended to modify disease, improve cognition, or treat neuropsychiatric symptoms. citeturn0search1turn0search3

Act (extracted details and web search results): Florbetapir (18F), marketed as Amyvid, is a radioactive PET tracer used to image beta‑amyloid neuritic plaques in the brain — it is a diagnostic imaging agent and the manufacturer/FDA materials state that radiologists should complete reader training to interpret Amyvid scans. citeturn0search0turn0search1turn0search4

Web search results used (brief): - FDA/press information and product description for Amyvid (Florbetapir F18 injection) — describes indication as PET imaging to estimate beta‑amyloid plaque density and notes reader training. citeturn0search0turn0search1 - Amyvid HCP pages describing indication, limitations, and need for trained readers. citeturn0search1turn0search6 - NEJM summary/discussion of florbetapir development and that it binds amyloid aggregates; notes reader training was used in clinical studies. citeturn0search3 - Regulatory/marketing notices describing availability and training resources. citeturn0search4turn0search5 - Background/wikipedia summary of florbetapir as an F‑18 amyloid PET tracer. citeturn0search12

Reflect: Given the above, the trial does not test a biologic or small‑molecule therapy, nor a cognitive enhancer or a neuropsychiatric treatment; it evaluates diagnostic image interpretation training. Per the category definitions, that is not a therapeutic trial — therefore classify as 'N/A'. (If you want, I can re-classify only if additional protocol text shows an interventional therapeutic drug rather than diagnostic imaging/training.)
